Projects.title: CODA: Making Music Practice More Meaningful
Projects.summary: A business venture where we develop a device to track how you play the drums and show you how to improve.

Process.title: CODA: Making Music Practice More Meaningful
text: An innovative business venture with the goal of creating a platform for musicians to share their experiences and track their progress. The device and platform is designed with the intention of helping aspiring musicians practice and stay engaged regardless of the initial struggles when learning an instrument.

Process.title: Market Research
text: Extensive Research was conducted into validity of the market. We analysed the potential size of the market we would be entering identify the specifc segments that we were interested in. Within these segments we analysed trends to justify to potential investors that the product being pitched was capable of strong growth and pitched at the Imperial Enterprise Lab as a part of the innovation pitch.

Process.title: Prototyping
text: To better present the concept to investors a set of “looks-like”, “feels-like and “works-like” prototypes were made. The “feels-like” prototypes were made through a series of iterations testing different weights, which allowed intensive user testing and the “works-like” prototype used an arudino combined with accelerometers and force sensors to demonstrate the key functionalities.

Process.title: Soft Launch
text: The final stage was to launch the website and video for the soft launch of the product. For this a series of high quality renders were developed to demonstrate the concept and a specific investor page was added for interested visitors. Furthermore, a Risk Register and 5 year Financial Projection was developed

Projects.title: Dog & Ball: The Automated Ball Thrower
Projects.summary: A product opportunity where we create a specialised product targetting sufferers of muscular skeletal issues and cater to the mass market.

Process.title: Dog & Ball: The Automated Ball Thrower
text: The dog and ball automated ball launcher is designed to enhance the relationship between person and there pet by making it easier them to exercise the Dog through the use of a ball. The automatic ball launcher is designed to remove the need to strain ones back or shoulder when throwing a ball during fetch.

Process.title: Ideation
text: This project began with large amounts of ideation using a double diamond approach to come up with different design ideas and launch mechanisms. Four different designs were sketched and roughly prototyped in blue foam.

Process.title: Analysis
text: Further research was conducted into the chosen mechanism and how viable it was with the low cost components found in relatively cheap donor products such as a hand drill. This required analysis of the required transmission ratios and power outputs. The launch velocities and ratios were plotted using MATLAB.

Process.title: Prototyping
text: In order to further demonstrate proof of concept, a physical test rig was produced using rapid-prototyping methods. Additionally the user experience was explored. The focus was to achieve the correct weight distribution and create an ergonomic shape.

Process.title: Final Prototype
text: A Cad model of the final prototype was designed and used to create a series of orthographic drawings and then the product was assembled and tested with our user groups.

Projects.title: Endo: The Open Source Continuum Robot
Projects.summary: A research project exploring how to make complex robotics more accessible through open source platforms.

Process.title: Endo: The Open Source Continuum Robot
text: A Continuum Manipulator is defined by its infinite degrees of freedom and is recognised within the field of robotics as a versatile tool specifically within medical fields. This project aimed to open up the technology and make it more available through the use of open source platforms such as GitHub and arduino. This would enable more researchers to access the field and furher develop the technology.

Process.title: Design
text: In accordance with the open source aspect the design of the robot utilised materials and production methods that were easily replicable. The designs were made using SOLIDWORKS and utilised a parametric design to enable other users to adjust key parameters such as spine length and diameter. These designs were made available on GitHub alongsie the Arduino control library.

button https://github.com/OpenSourceMedicalRobots/Endo-Continuum-Robot-Library Arduino Library

Process.title: Control Algorithm
text: One of the biggest hurdles in using continuum robots is the control mechanism. Due to the pliable nature of the robot, the kinematics is difficult and hard to mathematically model and therefore it is common to use an experimental approach to achieve a control mechanism. In order to enable this for future researches, an open source arduino library was developed and tested.

Process.title: TMRB Publication
text: Having completed the project I worked with the REDS LAB to focus on publishing my work in IEEE Transactions on Medical Robotics and Bionics
